channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
item.description: Best of long-form journalism this week.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: Roadside Bomb Kills 3 Policemen in Afghanistan
item.description: A remote-controlled roadside bomb killed three police officers on Sunday in southern Afghanistan, including a deputy provincial police chief.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Confidence Issues Linger as the Dreamliner Soars Again
item.description: Boeing’s Dreamliner is back in the air, but questions linger about the cause of the battery overheating, the technology fixes – and confidence.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A Boeing 787 of All Nippon Airways landing at the end of a test flight at Haneda International Airport in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: In Cairo, Rethinking the City From the Bottom Up
item.description: In the wake of their revolution, Egyptians must determine for themselves what their capital should look like: not just politically and socially, but also architecturally.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: The old neighborhood of Darb al-Ahmar in Cairo. A result of the revolution has been a frenzy of building, much of it improvised.

item.title: Jihad Discussions Led to Warning on Tamerlan Tsarnaev
item.description: Russian authorities never explained the reason for their concern until after the Boston Marathon bombings.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Shamshad Begum Indian Film Singer Dies at 94
item.description: Ms. Begum was one of the first female playback singers in Hindi cinema — she was heard but not seen on screen, as other actresses lip-synced her work.
item.dc:creator: By HARESH PANDYA

item.title: The Egyptian Revolution’s Transformation of Cairo, Block by Block
item.description: After decades of not being able to make decisions about their city, Cairenes are taking its development into their own hands.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Fleeing Violence in Pakistan, Hazaras Brave Uncertain Journey
item.description: Ethnic Hazaras, who have borne the brunt of recent violence in Pakistan, are increasingly seeking refuge in Australia, but they must travel a long and perilous path to get there.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ali, a Hazara originally from Quetta, in western Pakistan, now living in Karachi. The 26-year-old said he was quitting his accounting studies to leave for Australia.

item.title: Algeria’s President Abdelaziz Bouteflika Has Mini-Stroke
item.description: Algeria’s president was hospitalized on Saturday after having a mini-stroke without serious complications, the state news agency said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Fire Kills 4 Brothers at Camp for Syria Refugees
item.description: Four brothers who had fled the civil war in Syria were killed in a fire in the Zaatari refugee camp near Jordan’s northern border, the aid worker who runs the camp said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Immigrants Find it Cheaper to Send Money Home
item.description: Improvements not only make remittances an even more powerful means to chip away at poverty back home, but also expand the hard-won earnings of immigrants in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By NATALIE KITROEFF
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carmen Gonzalez, who immigrated from Mexico in 1991, says that the cost to send money home has dropped from $12 to $5.

item.title: Rapid Growth Creates Cities Within Cities in India
item.description: India’s crowded urban centers are divided not only by class but also by the legal status of where people live.

item.title: Diplomatic Memo: Bernard Bajolet, Leaving Afghanistan, Has His Say
item.description: At a farewell party for the French ambassador to Afghanistan, the guest of honor let the diplomatic mask slip to talk about the country’s future.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: In a farewell speech, Bernard Bajolet outlined the challenges facing Afghanistan.

item.title: Unauthorized Colonies Dot New Delhi, Seeking Legal Status
item.description: Across New Delhi, as many as five million residents live in unauthorized colonies, whether in slums, middle-class areas or even a few illegally constructed enclaves of the rich.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: New Ashok Nagar, an “unauthorized colony” in New Delhi.

item.title: Russian Officials Dismiss ‘Magnitsky List’
item.description: In Moscow, officials went on television to say that American sanctions on Russians accused of human rights violations would have absolutely no effect on them, thank you.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Italy Forms New Coalition Government to End Months of Political Stalemate
item.description: Prime Minister-elect Enrico Letta formed a rare coalition government uniting left and right to steer the nation out of the doldrums.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO

item.title: Plane Crash in Afghanistan Kills 4 International Troops
item.description: The Taliban did not immediately claim responsibility for the plane crash. and NATO said initial reports indicated no enemy activity in the area where the plane went down.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea Expected to Indict American
item.description: A tour operator from Washington State is accused of carrying out hostile acts against the North Korean government.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Chinese Subsidies Under Scrutiny
item.description: The European Commission began an investigation into industry claims that Chinese makers of solar glass benefit from illegal subsidies.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Rescues and Arrests in Building Collapse in Bangladesh
item.description: The police said that they had taken five people into custody in connection with Wednesday’s building collapse as violent protests continued in nearby Dhaka.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: One of the survivors rescued Saturday from a collapsed garment factory. At least 340 people are known to have been killed.

item.title: A Battered Dream for Tamerlan Tsarnaev, Then a Violent Path
item.description: Tamerlan Tsarnaev, a winner of Golden Gloves titles, was barred from a national boxing tournament because he was not a United States citizen.
item.dc:creator: By DEBORAH SONTAG, DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and SERGE F. KOVALESKI
item.media:description: Tamerlan Tsarnaev, right, lost at the Golden Gloves championships in 2009. A year later, a new citizenship rule blocked him.

item.title: Islamist Rebels’ Gains in Syria Create Dilemma for U.S.
item.description: The armed opposition fighting President Bashar al-Assad’s government has become radicalized, leaving the United States with no obvious allies.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Edlib News Network Enn, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image provided by citizen journalists shows Nusra Front rebels at an air base in Idlib.

item.title: Rebels From Darfur Attack in North Kordofan State
item.description: The foray into North Kordofan State is a rare venture outside Darfur and South Kordofan State for the rebels.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: The Beauty Market Resists Recession
item.description: Economic hard times have failed to dent the enthusiasm of Europeans for beauty treatments. But health experts are sounding alarms about potential health risks of some of those treatments.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Hong Kong Retains Allure as Retail Mecca
item.description: High rents to not detract from Hong Kong’s ability to lure high end retailers, especially with a flood of mainland Chinese spending heavily in the city.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:description: A busy intersection in Hong Kong's Causeway Bay shopping district in November.
